name: Heart Women & Girls
mission: HEART promotes sexual health literacy and sexual violence prevention in Muslim communities through health education, advocacy, research, and training.
theoryOfChange: By providing faith-inspired education and advocacy, HEART aims to uproot gendered violence and establish reproductive autonomy for Muslims through a trauma-informed, evidence-based approach.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat (Source: https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat)

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: ibn_sabil (+5); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 34/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with causal pathway
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: The impact rationale does not mention the significant deduction due to the small board size (2 members), which is a key factor in the overall score and risk deduction.

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Heart Women & Girls earns 42/100 due to good alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat (Source: https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: HEART promotes sexual health literacy and violence prevention through education, advocacy, and research.
The organization is zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy.
The charity reported total revenue of $1,089,496, a program expense ratio of 74.8%, working capital of 25.6 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
The organization provides various donation options and methods for supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The charity demonstrates high alignment for Muslim donors through its specialized advocacy and zakat eligibility, though its overall score is moderated by a lower direct impact rating.
areas_for_improvement: Limited direct impact data regarding cost per beneficiary
Opportunity to increase the program expense ratio toward industry benchmarks

dimension_explanations.alignment: HEART shows high alignment with the needs of the Muslim community by addressing urgent advocacy issues and sexual violence prevention [1]. Its status as a zakat-eligible organization further strengthens its fit for faith-based giving [2][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building and sexual health literacy, reporting a program expense ratio of 74.8% [3]. While it maintains a strong financial position with 25.6 months of working capital, the direct cost-effectiveness per beneficiary is not currently quantified [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: HEART empowers Muslim communities through sexual health literacy and the prevention of sexual violence.
strengths: Strong financial stability with 25.6 months of working capital
High fundraising efficiency with only $0.11 spent per $1 raised
Clear zakat eligibility and distribution policy
baseline_narrative.summary: HEART provides health education, advocacy, and research specifically tailored to the needs of Muslim women and girls [1]. The organization operates as a zakat-eligible entity, adhering to a specific zakat policy to support its mission [2].

all_citations.quote: Programs: Health Education, Advocacy, Research, Training, Survivor Care Fund

all_citations.claim: Silver Seal of Transparency from Candid

all_citations.quote: Zakat-eligible entity, adhering to a specific zakat policy

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The charity demonstrates high alignment for Muslim donors through its specialized advocacy and zakat eligibility, though its overall score is moderated by a lower direct impact rating.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="16">board size of only 2 members</cite>, which limits independent oversight and diverse perspectives.
There is currently <cite id="17">no public data on cost per beneficiary</cite>, making it difficult to assess the direct efficiency of program delivery.

bbb_assessment.summary: HEART is not currently evaluated by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is a grantee partner of the Birth Justice Initiative, suggesting some level of external validation.
risk_factors: <cite id="30">Board size of 2</cite> is significantly below the recommended minimum for nonprofit oversight
<cite id="31">Excessive working capital</cite> may suggest the organization is not deploying funds as quickly as it could
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="28">governance risks</cite> due to a small board and a lack of <cite id="29">external impact evaluations</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data, but governance and impact metrics are limited.

alignment.explanation: HEART offers <cite id="26">high Muslim donor fit</cite> by serving a <cite id="27">niche advocacy cause</cite> that is often neglected in the community.

credibility.explanation: HEART is a legitimate 501(c)(3) that has <cite id="20">operated for 16 years</cite> and holds a <cite id="21">Silver Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="22">expand its board of directors</cite> beyond the current two members to meet standard governance benchmarks.

impact.explanation: The organization reports a <cite id="23">74.8% program expense ratio</cite> in some filings, though other data suggests a <cite id="24">74.8% ratio</cite> when adjusted for management costs.
impact.improvement: Impact scores would improve by <cite id="25">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> to enable a clear cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Self-reported outcomes with limited external validation

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct program implementation rather than grantmaking

rich_narrative.headline: HEART empowers Muslim communities through sexual health literacy and the prevention of sexual violence.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support specialized advocacy and sexual health education within the Muslim community through a zakat-eligible organization.
donor_motivations: Want to address sensitive or 'taboo' issues within a faith-based framework
Prioritize funding niche organizations that fill gaps left by large charities
Value high financial stability and low fundraising overhead
Seek to fulfill zakat through advocacy and education
giving_considerations: The organization is small, meaning individual donations have high visibility
Governance is currently centralized with a very small board
Impact is measured through education and training rather than direct aid
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale international emergency relief or those who require rigorous RCT-level evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects that while a theory of change is documented, there is a lack of independent evaluation and specific beneficiary cost metrics.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: HEART uses health education and advocacy to build sexual health literacy, aiming for a world where individuals are valued and safe.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that advocacy and training programs effectively change community behaviors and safety outcomes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a small organization in a niche space, HEART has significant room to expand its training and survivor care programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: HEART is unique for its <cite id="32">specific focus on sexual health literacy</cite> compared to broader legal advocacy peers.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses more on direct shelter and legal advocacy

strengths.detail: The organization spends only <cite id="10">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite>, significantly outperforming many larger humanitarian peers.
HEART maintains <cite id="11">$2,020,072 in total assets</cite> with minimal liabilities, providing a robust safety net for its advocacy work.
The charity has a <cite id="12">clear zakat policy</cite> and serves eligible categories including <cite id="13">ibn sabil (the wayfarer)</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: HEART's financial health is characterized by extreme stability and efficiency. With a <cite id="14">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 to $0.11</cite> per dollar raised, the organization ensures that the vast majority of donor contributions are available for its core mission. Furthermore, its <cite id="15">working capital ratio of 25.6 months</cite> indicates that HEART could sustain its current operations for over two and a half years without additional funding, a rare level of security for a small advocacy nonprofit.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">2010</cite>, HEART (Health Education, Advocacy, Research, and Training) is a niche advocacy organization dedicated to <cite id="2">promoting sexual health literacy</cite> and preventing sexual violence within Muslim communities. Operating primarily in the United States and Canada, the organization addresses sensitive topics through a faith-informed lens, providing <cite id="3">health education, advocacy, and survivor care</cite>. In the 2023 fiscal year, HEART reported <cite id="4">total revenue of $1,089,496</cite>, largely driven by <cite id="5">contributions totaling $1,041,599</cite>. The organization maintains a <cite id="6">Silver Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, reflecting a commitment to public disclosure. While the organization is relatively small, it fills a critical gap in the Muslim nonprofit sector by tackling issues of sexual health and violence that are often underserved. HEART is <cite id="7">zakat-eligible</cite>, maintaining a policy that directs funds toward specific categories of need, including <cite id="8">the poor (fuqara) and needy (masakin)</cite>. Financially, the charity demonstrates significant stability, holding <cite id="9">25.6 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, which ensures long-term viability but suggests a high capacity for additional program deployment.
